support_summary: Wolframin (WFS1) provides feedback inhibition on ATF6 signaling by recruiting the HRD1 E3 ligase to target full-length ATF6 for proteasomal degradation.

functions.cellular_process: Wolframin (WFS1) acts as a negative regulator of the ATF6α signaling pathway by forming a complex with and stabilizing the E3 ubiquitin ligase HRD1. This WFS1-HRD1 complex then targets the full-length, inactive form of ATF6α for ubiquitination and subsequent degradation by the proteasome.
functions.effect_description: This interaction establishes a negative feedback loop that attenuates the Unfolded Protein Response (UPR) by reducing the available pool of ATF6α, thereby preventing its hyperactivation and suppressing the transcription of its target genes.
biological_consequence: WFS1 expression → Stabilization of HRD1 E3 ligase → Recruitment of full-length ATF6α to the WFS1-HRD1 complex → Ubiquitination of ATF6α → Proteasomal degradation of ATF6α → Attenuation of UPR signaling
specific_effects: WFS1 facilitates the interaction between HRD1 and full-length ATF6α.
Loss of WFS1 leads to an accumulation of ATF6α and dysregulated ER stress signaling.

evidence.paper_title: Wolfram syndrome 1 gene negatively regulates ER stress signaling in rodent and human cells
evidence.relevant_quote: Moreover, WFS1 stabilized the E3 ubiquitin ligase HRD1, brought ATF6alpha to the proteasome, and enhanced its ubiquitination and proteasome-mediated degradation, leading to suppression of ER stress signaling.

mechanism: Wolframin (WFS1) acts as a negative regulator of the ATF6α signaling pathway by forming a complex with and stabilizing the E3 ubiquitin ligase HRD1. This WFS1-HRD1 complex then targets the full-length, inactive form of ATF6α for ubiquitination and subsequent degradation by the proteasome.
effect: This interaction establishes a negative feedback loop that attenuates the Unfolded Protein Response (UPR) by reducing the available pool of ATF6α, thereby preventing its hyperactivation and suppressing the transcription of its target genes.
summary: ATF6 inhibits WFS1 to modulate atf6 degradation, ultimately affecting attenuation of upr signaling.

evidence.paper_title: Wolfram syndrome 1 gene negatively regulates ER stress signaling in rodent and human cells
evidence.relevant_quote: Moreover, WFS1 stabilized the E3 ubiquitin ligase HRD1, brought ATF6alpha to the proteasome, and enhanced its ubiquitination and proteasome-mediated degradation, leading to suppression of ER stress signaling.
